awd_titl_txt: REU Site:  Exploring 21st Century Careers in the Biological Sciences: A Comparative Regenerative Biology Approach
awd_abstract_narration:
This REU Site award to Mount Desert Island (MDI) Biological Laboratory, located in Salisbury Cove, ME, will support the training of 10 undergraduate students for 10 weeks during the summers of 2019- 2021. Students will explore topics related to regenerative biology and aging using a variety of animal models, including zebrafish, salamanders, and nematodes. Students will contribute to the understanding of how limbs and organs regenerate under varying environmental conditions. Additional opportunities for students include learning about career options and deeper scientific concepts thru scheduled seminars, symposia, and workshops. To experience the entrepreneurial facet of scientific research, all students will participate in an entrepreneurship workshop in which they will learn about career avenues for scientists whose research interests span disciplinary boundaries. In addition, all students will attend a bioinformatics workshop in which they will learn how to work with big data sets as well as career paths in the evolving field of computational biology. 

It is anticipated that a total of 30 students, primarily from schools with limited research opportunities, will be trained in the program. Students will learn how research is conducted and how to communicate their research findings through participation in a weekly science communication course and an on-campus Summer Science Symposium at the culmination of their REU experience. It is possible that students will present their results in other scientific venues and contribute to scientific publications in peer-reviewed journals. A common web-based assessment tool used by all REU Site programs funded by the Division of Biological Infrastructure will be used to determine the effectiveness of the training program. In addition, students will participate in a campus-wide survey to determine how to improve the summer research experience for future students at MDI Biological Laboratory. Students will be tracked after the program in order to determine their career paths. Students will be asked to respond to an automatic email sent via the NSF reporting system. More information about the program is available by visiting https://mdibl.org/education/hs-undergrad/undergraduate-applications/reu/ or by contacting the PI (Dr. Jane Disney at jdisney@mdibl.org) or the co-PI (Dr. Dustin Updike at dupdike@mdibl.org).

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Undergraduates who participated in the MDI Biological Laboratory?s NSF REU program, called ?Exploring 21st Century Careers in the Biological Sciences: A Comparative Regenerative Biology Approach?, engaged in a unique 10-week scientific experience conducting research in comparative regenerative biology and related topics using a variety of animal models, including zebrafish, axolotls, and round worms. Students in our REU program learned about career options as they participated in an active scientific summer community and attended seminars and supporting workshops. Students participated in a uniquely designed Innovation Course where they learned how complex problems are addressed through research and innovation. Students learned about career paths within different fields of research as they followed the development of a fictional product from discovery to commercialization. Students were introduced to the process of patenting new innovations as well as when to file a new patent. The Innovation Course provided a broad perspective on steps required to develop a new technology and examined related societal issues such the role of AI in innovation, the importance of diversity and inclusion in research, and integrating environmental sustainability in the development process. In addition, all students attended introductory sessions in bioinformatics and had the opportunity to get one-on-one support for the bioinformatics aspects of their research. They learned about working with big data sets as well as career paths in computational biology. Through participation in a weekly scientific communication course, students learned to communicate the broader impacts of their NSF-funded work to both scientific and public audiences, and the importance of communication in achieving their career goals. As part of our long-standing commitment to the NSF REU program (since 1993) and mission to educate the next generation of biologists, we selected 32 undergraduate students over the three-year plus one-year extension of our REU program at MDI Biological Laboratory. Targeted students included all collegiate levels (from rising freshmen to rising seniors). We considered student applicants interested in molecular and cell biology, genetics, biochemistry, and developmental biology, as these subject areas relate to regenerative biology and reflect the scientific expertise of our research mentors. We were able to pivot when the pandemic hit in 2020, offering remote research experiences in computational biology and related topics for six students, providing online mentoring and access to summer programming via Zoom. We joined the community of other NSF BIO REU sites that were providing remote experiences for students and contributed to a large-scale evaluation of the remote research experiences for students and mentors, the results of which were published.  

The intellectual merit of our REU program resides in the multiple and diverse opportunities that students had to explore career options related to basic biological research against a backdrop of intensive investigative experiences in regenerative biology. Students joined a unique scientific community comprised of researchers who utilize diverse animal models and scientific approaches to understand the basics of regenerative biology. Some of these researchers are applying for patents with plans to launch new companies. Students had the opportunity to learn about these research-related activities via workshops and seminars and by interacting with the scientists and bioentrepreneurs who are incubating STEM companies on our campus.

Our REU program provided research opportunities for historically excluded and underrepresented groups in science, technology, engineering, and mathematics (STEM) majors. Over 50 percent of our program participants fell into this category. In addition, our program provided opportunities to students from institutions where research opportunities are limited, such as primarily undergraduate institutions and community colleges. By engaging these populations in research we contributed to the nation-wide effort of the NSF REU program to broaden and diversify the scientific workforce of the future. In order to help students to prepare for 21st century careers in science, students were not only immersed in basic research but will also had outlets to explore a myriad of other avenues that require experience with and deep knowledge of basic scientific research, including biotechnology, bioinformatics, and bioentrepreneurship, all of which open doors to a variety of career opportunities. Through immersion in the daily life of our scientific community, students established networks with scientists, mentors, instructors, and peers who will provide them with a lifetime of connections and support that will benefit them on their career trajectories.
